paddyhoran commented on a change in pull request #2746: ARROW-2483: [Rust] use bit-packing for boolean vectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2746#discussion_r224776443
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/src/array.rs
 ##########
 @@ -285,6 +282,123 @@ def_primitive_array!(DataType::Int64, i64);
 def_primitive_array!(DataType::Float32, f32);
 def_primitive_array!(DataType::Float64, f64);
 
+/// Array whose elements are of boolean types.
+pub struct BooleanArray {
+    data: ArrayDataRef,
+    raw_values: RawPtrBox<u8>,
+}
+
+impl BooleanArray {
+    pub fn new(length: i64, values: Buffer, null_count: i64, offset: i64) -> Self {
+        let array_data = ArrayData::builder(DataType::Boolean)
+            .len(length)
+            .add_buffer(values)
+            .null_count(null_count)
+            .offset(offset)
+            .build();
+        BooleanArray::from(array_data)
+    }
+
+    /// Returns a `Buffer` holds all the values of this array.
+    ///
+    /// Note this doesn't take account into the offset of this array.
 
 Review comment:
   Shouldn't this be something like "Note this does not take the offset of the underlying `ArrayData` into account"

sunchao commented on a change in pull request #2746: ARROW-2483: [Rust] use bit-packing for boolean vectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2746#discussion_r224930767
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/src/array.rs
 ##########
 @@ -285,6 +282,123 @@ def_primitive_array!(DataType::Int64, i64);
 def_primitive_array!(DataType::Float32, f32);
 def_primitive_array!(DataType::Float64, f64);
 
+/// Array whose elements are of boolean types.
+pub struct BooleanArray {
+    data: ArrayDataRef,
+    raw_values: RawPtrBox<u8>,
+}
+
+impl BooleanArray {
+    pub fn new(length: i64, values: Buffer, null_count: i64, offset: i64) -> Self {
+        let array_data = ArrayData::builder(DataType::Boolean)
+            .len(length)
+            .add_buffer(values)
+            .null_count(null_count)
+            .offset(offset)
+            .build();
+        BooleanArray::from(array_data)
+    }
+
+    /// Returns a `Buffer` holds all the values of this array.
+    ///
+    /// Note this doesn't take account into the offset of this array.
 
 Review comment:
   Yes offset technically is a property of `ArrayData`. However it is also (indirectly) a property of a `Array` since `ArrayData` encapsulates the common properties for all arrays. So, IMO this comment should be fine. 

----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

sunchao commented on issue #2746: ARROW-2483: [Rust] use bit-packing for boolean vectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2746#issuecomment-429481431
 
 
   Thanks @kszucs and @paddyhoran for the review. 
   
   > We probably don't need Bitmap with this in place, right?
   
   `Bitmap` is a thin wrapper around the `get_bit` operations, so it can be removed easily if we decide to. The `BooleanArray` is an array type which contains both a null vector and a value vector. The common of the two is that they all use the same bit operations.

----------------------------------------------------------------

crepererum commented on a change in pull request #2746: ARROW-2483: [Rust] use bit-packing for boolean vectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2746#discussion_r224953525
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/src/util/bit_util.rs
 ##########
 @@ -47,6 +47,12 @@ pub fn get_bit(data: &[u8], i: i64) -> bool {
     (data[(i / 8) as usize] & BIT_MASK[(i % 8) as usize]) != 0
 }
 
+/// Returns whether bit at position `i` in `data` is set or not
+#[inline]
+pub fn get_bit_raw(data: *const u8, i: i64) -> bool {
+    unsafe { (*data.offset((i / 8) as isize) & BIT_MASK[(i % 8) as usize]) != 0 }
 
 Review comment:
   Use bit operations instead of integer decision and modulo here, because both are really slow (and you cannot always rely on the compiler to optimize them). Also, why is the offset allowed to be negative? Also, who's checking the bounds of that access? 

----------------------------------------------------------------

 Review comment:
   Isn't this the one situation where using a wildcard is acceptable (i.e. bringing all the contents of the module into scope so it can be tested)?

sunchao commented on a change in pull request #2746: ARROW-2483: [Rust] use bit-packing for boolean vectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2746#discussion_r225278397
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/src/util/bit_util.rs
 ##########
 @@ -47,6 +47,12 @@ pub fn get_bit(data: &[u8], i: i64) -> bool {
     (data[(i / 8) as usize] & BIT_MASK[(i % 8) as usize]) != 0
 }
 
+/// Returns whether bit at position `i` in `data` is set or not
+#[inline]
+pub fn get_bit_raw(data: *const u8, i: i64) -> bool {
+    unsafe { (*data.offset((i / 8) as isize) & BIT_MASK[(i % 8) as usize]) != 0 }
 
 Review comment:
   I basically followed the [C++ version](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/cpp/src/arrow/util/bit-util.h#L318) for the implementation, but I think you raised some very good points here. Replaced the ops with bit ops, and also added bound check in the caller site. 
   
   For the `i64` type issue, I think it is valid to change to `usize` but that's a broader change than this PR. I'll do it separately.

crepererum commented on a change in pull request #2746: ARROW-2483: [Rust] use bit-packing for boolean vectors
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/2746#discussion_r225406418
 
 

 ##########
 File path: rust/src/util/bit_util.rs
 ##########
 @@ -44,13 +44,22 @@ fn round_upto_power_of_2(num: i64, factor: i64) -> i64 {
 /// Returns whether bit at position `i` in `data` is set or not
 #[inline]
 pub fn get_bit(data: &[u8], i: i64) -> bool {
-    (data[(i / 8) as usize] & BIT_MASK[(i % 8) as usize]) != 0
+    (data[(i >> 3) as usize] & BIT_MASK[(i & 7) as usize]) != 0
+}
+
+/// Returns whether bit at position `i` in `data` is set or not.
+///
+/// Note this doesn't do any bound checking, for performance reason. The caller is
+/// responsible to guarantee that `i` is within bounds.
+#[inline]
+pub fn get_bit_raw(data: *const u8, i: i64) -> bool {
+    unsafe { (*data.offset((i >> 3) as isize) & BIT_MASK[(i & 7) as usize]) != 0 }
 
 Review comment:
   What happens if i is negative?

   Then the function must be marked as unsafe.

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description: Boolean vectors now use 1 byte for each value, which seems wasteful. We could use bit-packing to store the values, similar to the CPP implementation.

comments.body: Would like to take this one. [~wesmckinn], [~xhochy]: can you add me as a contributor? Thanks.
